tutorial.title: HTML Accessibility Basics
tutorial.descriptionContent: Learn the accessibility basics to improve your HTML

lessons.title: Intro 1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Accessibility is the practice of ensuring websites are accessible to the largest number of users possible.

Some users may need assistive technologies like screen readers or zooming devices that need coding support to access content.

lessons.title: Intro to a11y 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
But accessibility is not only about screen readers. It also helps users who use different devices or have slow internet connections.

One of the ways to code accessible websites is by using semantic HTML. Let's start coding!

lessons.title: Generic HTML Elements
lessons.interactiveContent:
Generic HTML tags like div and span are containers. However, they don't provide context. Other tags are meaningful, like h1 , ul or body.

Can you code the meaningful HTML tag to create an unordered list?

Make sure to pick ul, followed by ul.

lessons.title: Meaningful tags
lessons.interactiveContent:
Screen readers have to be able to interpret HTML elements to function properly. A <button> is a better option than this div element.

We'll learn what we can do when we encounter these meaningless containers in future lessons.

Make sure to pick Click here!.

lessons.title: Heading order
lessons.interactiveContent:
HTML order is important for accessibility. Skipping heading ranks can be confusing, so we should always order them sequentially.

Make sure to pick h1 followed by h1 and then h2, h2, h3, h3.

lessons.title: H1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Another key implementation for accessibility is that webpages must only have one h1 heading.

Make sure to pick h1, followed by h1.

lessons.title: Question: a11y
lessons.interactiveContent:
Why is the concept of accessibility important when coding?

It allows a website to be accessible to the largest number of users possibleIt only helps screen readers

It allows a website to be accessible to the largest number of users possible.

lessons.title: Question 2: Generic Elements
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which HTML elements are considered meaningless?

div and spandiv and main

div and span.

lessons.title: Question 3: div
lessons.interactiveContent:
What is the accessibility disadvantage of using div tags?

div tags do not provide any context for screen readersdiv tags do not have default styling

div tags do not provide any context for screen readers.

lessons.title: Question 4: h1
lessons.interactiveContent:
How many <h1> should we include in a webpage to consider it accessible?

Only oneAs many as we want, but properly ordered

Only one.

lessons.title: Example 1: Meaningful tags
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use the header tag and the main tag to separate the code into relevant sections.

Make sure to pick header followed by header and then main, main.

lessons.title: Example 2: headings
lessons.interactiveContent:
Follow the sequence and include the appropriate headings in order.

Make sure to pick <h1> followed by </h1> and then <h2>, </h2>, <h3>, </h3>.

lessons.title: Example 3: More semantic tags
lessons.interactiveContent:
Choose the semantic tags that correspond with the content.

Make sure to pick <nav> followed by </nav> and then <footer>, </footer>.

lessons.title: Intro
lessons.interactiveContent:
We've seen how keeping our code tidy and contextualized is a great way to contribute to accessibility.

But we can do more! We can also include relevant HTML tags and attributes to help improve accessibility.

lessons.title: Button vs link
lessons.interactiveContent:
We must use the correct tags for their purpose. For example, <button> when there's an action and <a> when there's a redirection.

Make sure to pick <a href="mimo.org"> followed by </a> and then <button>, </button>.

lessons.title: Descriptive actions
lessons.interactiveContent:
It's important to use descriptive action calls for buttons and links so that users know what will happen if they interact with them.

Add appropriate texts to indicate the action of the button and the redirection of the link.

Make sure to pick Click for more info, followed by Visit the supplier website.

lessons.title: Alt
lessons.interactiveContent:
Alternative texts give context to screen readers and provide useful descriptions when images fail to load. Fill the image's alt attribute.

Make sure to pick cat in a backpack.

lessons.title: Empty alt
lessons.interactiveContent:
Image descriptions should be concise and detailed. When images are just decorations, we include empty alternative texts alt="" .

Make sure to pick alt="".

lessons.title: lang
lessons.interactiveContent:
Another helpful attribute is lang. When we define it correctly in the html tag, it helps screen readers know what language to use.

Make sure to pick lang="en".

lessons.title: Question 1: button and link
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which tag should we use to create a "buy" action?

<button>Buy</button><a>Buy</a>

Make sure to pick <button>Buy</button>.

lessons.title: Question 2: anchor tag
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which tag should we use to redirect to another page?

<a><button>

Make sure to pick <a>.

lessons.title: Question 3: alt
lessons.interactiveContent:
When should images have empty alternative texts alt="" ?

When images are just decorationsOnly in relevant images

When images are just decorations.

lessons.title: Question 4: create buttons
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we create a button with <div>Action</div>, can we say it's accessible?

NoYes

Make sure to pick No.

lessons.title: Example 1: Button
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a button that allows the user to subscribe to a newsletter.

Make sure to pick <button>Subscribe</button>.

lessons.title: Example 2: lang attribute
lessons.interactiveContent:
Register the appropriate lang attribute.

Make sure to pick "en".

lessons.title: Example 3: Descriptive Link
lessons.interactiveContent:
Choose the most meaningful link description for the anchor tag.

Make sure to pick Mimo Homepage.

lessons.title: Example 4: Concise alt
lessons.interactiveContent:
Choose the appropriate and more concise alternative text for this img.

Make sure to pick "Forest view".
